characterList.description: An older man with gray hair and a mustache, wearing a blue shirt and jeans. He is an artist.
characterList.name: Ken Done

characterList.description: Ken Done's friend, an architect who designed a house for Ken. Only appears in a portrait painted by Ken Done.
characterList.name: Glenn Murcutt

content_metadata.description: A video story about the artist Ken Done, detailing his connection to Sydney Harbour, and showcasing his art and artistic journey alongside a personal narrative.

qAndA.question: What type of boat does Ken Done use to enjoy Sydney Harbour?
How old was Ken Done when he had his first art exhibition?
What colors are the glasses in the portrait of Glenn Murcutt?

qAndA.answer: They symbolize the enduring natural beauty of Sydney Harbour, untouched by development.
qAndA.question: What is the significance of the superimposed images in Scene 4?

qAndA.answer: While there are moments of pensiveness and reflection, the overall mood is positive and inspiring. Ken Done’s love for his art, his connection to Sydney, and his optimistic outlook on life shine through.
qAndA.question: What is the underlying mood of the video?

narrativeProgression.description: Establishes the setting (Sydney Harbour) and introduces the subject of the video (Ken Done).

videoEditingDetails.description: Fade in from black to a view of sailboats on water, framed by trees.
Title card 'KEN DONE' appears over the water view.
Cut to interior shot of Ken Done in a gallery.

activities.description: Ken Done stands in a gallery with his arms crossed, talking about his art.

characterInteraction.description: Ken Done speaks directly to the camera.

narrativeProgression.description: Introduction to Ken Done's artistic background and his primary focus as a painter.

videoEditingDetails.description: Cut to close-up shots of two dog portraits by Ken Done while he talks about other art forms.
Cut back to Ken Done in the gallery.

activities.description: Ken Done sits by a window overlooking the water, talking about his early success and his connection to Sydney Harbour.

characterInteraction.description: Ken Done speaks directly to the camera.

scenes.contextualRelevance: Ken Done emphasizes the importance of individual experience in art appreciation, highlighting the subjectivity of "good" art.

keyMoments.changeDescription: Shift from a contemplative mood to a more engaged and passionate mood as Ken Done enters his studio and interacts with his artwork.

narrativeProgression.description: Ken Done reflects on overcoming the challenges of early success and finding his own artistic voice. He emphasizes his strong connection to Sydney Harbour.

scenes.thematicElements: Early success, artistic development, personal connection to place
scenes.title: Reflection & Artistic Development

videoEditingDetails.description: Cut to shots of Ken Done's paintings in a gallery while he discusses his early commercial work.
Cut to Ken Done in his studio, holding a large painting of the Sydney Opera House.
Cut back to Ken Done sitting by the window.

activities.description: Ken Done walks through his garden towards his studio, talking about his connection to Sydney.
Ken Done stands by the water, talking about the unchanging parts of Sydney Harbour and his experience feeding fish.

characterInteraction.description: Ken Done speaks directly to the camera.

scenes.contextualRelevance: The superimposed images symbolize the connection between the past and present, emphasizing the enduring natural beauty of Sydney Harbour.

narrativeProgression.description: Ken Done reinforces his deep connection to Sydney and its natural beauty.

scenes.title: Connection to Sydney Harbour

videoEditingDetails.description: Cut to a close-up of Ken Done's face while he talks about kayaking and feeding fish.
Cut to Ken Done standing by the water.
Superimposed image of a flower floating on water and a view of houses along the harbor shoreline while Ken Done talks about the unchanged parts of the harbor.

activities.description: Ken Done stands in his studio, talking about his inspiration from Sydney Harbour and his goal to capture its beauty in his paintings.
Cut to different paintings by Ken Done while he talks about the influence of the harbor on his art.

characterInteraction.description: Ken Done speaks directly to the camera.

keyMoments.changeDescription: Shift from a contemplative mood to a more energetic and vibrant mood as the montage of Ken Done’s colorful paintings begins.

narrativeProgression.description: Ken Done explains how his surroundings inspire his art, particularly his focus on capturing the essence of Sydney Harbour.

scenes.thematicElements: Inspiration, nature's beauty, artistic process, environment's influence on art
scenes.title: Inspiration from Sydney

videoEditingDetails.description: Cut to a rapid montage of Ken Done’s paintings showcasing Sydney Harbor and related themes.

activities.description: Cut to a gallery showcasing Ken Done’s portrait of Glenn Murcutt.
Cut back to Ken Done sitting by the window, talking about the portrait and its simplicity.

characterInteraction.description: Ken Done speaks directly to the camera. The portrait of Glenn Murcutt represents an implied interaction between the two friends.

scenes.contextualRelevance: Ken Done’s self-deprecating humor about his own self-portrait adds a layer of lightheartedness to the scene.

narrativeProgression.description: Introduction to Ken Done's portrait of Glenn Murcutt and his artistic approach to capturing his subject’s essence.

scenes.title: Portrait of Glenn Murcutt

videoEditingDetails.description: Fade in from black to a gallery setting.
Cut to Ken Done sitting by the window.

content_metadata.title: Ken Done - Portrait Story

trimmingSuggestions.description: The close-up shots of the dog portraits could be removed to maintain focus on Ken Done's primary medium of painting.
The section about Ken Done feeding fish could be shortened to keep the focus on his artistic inspiration from the harbor.

text_to_speech: - I like to make pictures. I've made a few sculptures, I've made a little bit of pottery, but basically I'm a painter. I'm not complaining, but I've had to overcome a lot of early success in the sense that the early things that people saw were very commercial things. (soft ethereal music) I was 40 when I had my first exhibition. It's quite old, really. But, that's just the way it was for me. If you like visual things, you know, that's what you like, you like all kinds of things and the only criteria should be, was it any good? You know, do you like it? I am very Sydney. I live beside Sydney Harbour which is a fantastic place to be. I kayak on the harbour, I feed the fish, I don't like to catch them anymore. I feed them, in fact, if anybody comes down here and they say, is there any fish around? I say, oh, no, there's no fish around here. No fish around here. But of course there are, top of the tide, there's eight Big Bream, I almost know them by name, come around each morning. There's parts of the harbour close by here, where we live, that hasn't changed forever. No houses, look exactly the same as when aboriginal people lived here or even later when Captain Cook came through. That's one of the great things about Sydney, I think, is that they've still preserved that natural landscape in some parts. Such a beautiful place. Almost inevitably you'll make pictures that try to be beautiful. You can't be as beautiful as itself, you can never be as beautiful as nature, you can not. But all you can do is to use that environment to lead you to make a painting that somehow might have the feeling of it. It's a complicated picture and it clearly set out to show that there's a kind of public face that I have. That's most of the time smiling and most of the time optimistic. But there's another face, maybe another even two faces within there that I hope shows a sadder side or a different kind of sensitivity. Glenn designed a house for us. We've known him a long time, he's a lovely man. And I did make a small drawing, but I wanted to make the painting as simple and as elegant as one of his buildings. I love the fact that in the portrait gallery, you've sometimes shown them both together and it just shows his elegant simplicity against the kind of complication of my self portrait which, you know, I would say straight to the psychiatrist, looking at that painting. (laughs)

I'm a painter. I'm not complaining, but I've had to overcome a lot of early success in
the sense that the early things that people saw were very commercial things. I was 40 when
I had my first exhibition, which quite old, really. But that's just the way it was for me.
If you like visual things, you know, that's what you like. You like all kinds of things
and the only criteria should be, was it any good? Do you like it?
I am very Sydney. I live beside Sydney Harbour, which is a fantastic place to be. I kayak
on the harbour. I feed the fish. I don't like to catch them anymore. I feed them. In fact,
if anybody comes down here and they say, I say, I know there's no fish around here. No
fish around here. But of course, there are top of the tide. There's eight big brima, almost
known by name. Come around each morning. There's parts of the harbour close by here where we
live that hasn't changed forever at no houses. We look exactly the same as when Aboriginal
people lived here or even later when Capcom Cook came through. That's one of the great
things about Sydney, I think, is that they've still preserved that natural landscape in some
parts. It's such a beautiful place, almost inevitably, you'll make pictures that try to
be beautiful. You can't be as beautiful as yourself. You can never be as beautiful as nature.
You cannot. But all you can do is to use that environment to lead you to make a painting
that somehow might have the feeling of it. It's a complicated picture and it clearly set out to
show that there's a kind of public face that I have that's most of the time smiling and most
of the time optimistic. But there's another face, maybe another even two faces within there,
that I hope shows a sad aside or a different kind of sensitivity. Glen designed a house for us.
We've known him a long time. He's a lovely man. And I did make a small drawing, but I wanted to
make the painting as simple and as elegant as one of his buildings. I love the fact that in the
portrait gallery you've sometimes shown them both together and it just shows his elegant simplicity
against the kind of complication of myself, Portrait, which I would say straight to the psychiatrist
looking at that by the way.

youtube_description:
Iconic Australian artist Ken Done discusses his life and career as a painter

---------------------------------------------

About the National Portrait Gallery

We collect and share portraits of notable Australians, and invite you to contemplate and appreciate our nation's identity, history, culture, creativity and diversity.

Subscribe to this channel at: http://goo.gl/GYIgsq – and join our other social media channels as follows:

- Facebook: https://facebook.com/PortraitAu
- Twitter: https://twitter.com/PortraitAu
- Instagram: https://instagram.com/PortraitAu

More information: https://portrait.gov.au
